articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
A question:
If you copy a code sample that uses two-space indentation and you want to convert it to four-space indentation, whatâ€™s the *fastest* and easiest option?
Matt Stauffer, Twitter

I wrote about doing this in Sublime Text a â€¦
The post One Way to Convert Code Indentation appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: One Way to Convert Code Indentation

articles.author: Eli Penner
articles.description:
Todayâ€™s websites are overflowing with animationsâ€”often too many. They get in the way of the content and slow down our busy users. But at the same time: theyâ€™re wonderful. They bring websites to life, are fun to implement and â€¦
The post Stealing Game Animation Techniques to Engage Users appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: Stealing Game Animation Techniques to Engage Users

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
This is a bit of advice for developers on Macs Iâ€™ve heard quite a few times, and Iâ€™ll echo it: go into System Preferences > General > Show scroll bars and set to always. This isnâ€™t about you, itâ€™s â€¦
The post Scrollbar Reflowing appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: Scrollbar Reflowing

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
(This is a sponsored post.)
Free event hosted by Netlify coming up next week (Wednesday, August 25th): Architecting with Next.js. Itâ€™s just a little half-day thing. No brainer.
Join us for a special event where weâ€™ll highlight business 
â€¦
The post Architecting With Next.js appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: Architecting With Next.js

articles.author: Charlie Gerard
articles.description:
Solid is a reactive JavaScript library for creating user interfaces without a virtual DOM. It compiles templates down to real DOM nodes once and wraps updates in fine-grained reactions so that when state updates, only the related code runs.
This â€¦
The post Introduction to the Solid JavaScript Library appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: Introduction to the Solid JavaScript Library

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
You canâ€™t just do @media (prefers-reduced-data: no-preference) alone because, as Kilian Valkhof says:
[â€¦] that would be false if either there was no support (since the browser wouldnâ€™t understand the media query) or if itÂ wasÂ supported but the 
â€¦
The post Detecting Media Query Support in CSS and JavaScript appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: Detecting Media Query Support in CSS and JavaScript

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.title: Native JavaScript Routing?

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
I appreciated this bit of nuance from a post on Vigetâ€™s blog:
There could be a whole article written about the many flavours of Tailwind, but broadly speaking those flavours are:
1. Stock tailwind, ie. no changes to the 
â€¦
The post â€œDisambiguating Tailwindâ€ appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: â€œDisambiguating Tailwindâ€

articles.author: Ganesh Dahal
articles.description:
Frontity is a WordPress-focused React-based server-side dynamic-rendering framework (phew!) that allows us to create fast headless websites. Chris has a good introduction to Frontity. I guess you could think of it like Next.js for WordPress. And while the demand â€¦
The post Creating a Headless WordPress Site With Frontity appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: Creating a Headless WordPress Site With Frontity

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.title: The Big Gotcha With Custom Properties

articles.author: Nader Dabit
articles.description:
Nuxt is a JavaScript framework that extends the existing functionality of Vue.js with features like server-side rendering, static page generation, file-based routing, and automatic code splitting among other things.
Iâ€™ve been enjoying using frameworks like Nuxt and Next because they â€¦
The post Using Nuxt and Supabase for  a Multi-User Blogging App appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: Using Nuxt and Supabase for  a Multi-User Blogging App

articles.author: Shadid Haque
articles.description:
(This is a sponsored post.)
In this article, we will discuss how we can applyÂ schema stitchingÂ across multiple Fauna instances. We will also discuss how to combine other GraphQL services and data sources with Fauna in one graph.â€¦
The post Implementing a single GraphQL across multiple data sources appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: Implementing a single GraphQL across multiple data sources

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
Over at the JS Party podcast:
[Kend C. Dodds]: [â€¦] ask anybody whoâ€™s done regular, old CSS and theyâ€™ll tell you that â€œI donâ€™t know if itâ€™s okay for me to change this, so Iâ€™m gonna duplicate it.â€ And now 
â€¦
The post â€œWe had 90% unused CSS because everybody was afraid to touch the old stuffâ€ appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: â€œWe had 90% unused CSS because everybody was afraid to touch the old stuffâ€

articles.author: Paulina Hetman
articles.description:
Have you already tried using WordPress headlessly with Gatsby? If you havenâ€™t, you might check this article around the new Gatsby source plugin for WordPress; gatsby-source-wordpress is the official source plugin introduced in March 2021 as a part of the â€¦
The post Native Search vs. Jetpack Instant Search in Headless WordPress With Gatsby appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: Native Search vs. Jetpack Instant Search in Headless WordPress With Gatsby

articles.author: Chris Coyier
articles.description:
Dave points to Sarahâ€™s post on Developer Experience (DX) at Netlify. Part of what Sarah did there is lay out what the role means. Itâ€™s a three-part thing:
Integrations Engineering (e.g. features)
Developer Experience Engineering (e.g. building integrations 
â€¦
The post DX, to Whom? appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.
articles.title: DX, to Whom?

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine â€” For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: In this article, Leonardo explains how to use a "multi-monorepo" approach for making the development experience faster, yet keeping your PHP packages private. This solution can be especially beneficial for PRO plugin creators.
articles.title: Creating A Public/Private Multi-Monorepo For PHP Projects

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Portia Burton)
articles.description: In this article, youâ€™ll learn how to save hours of tedious work of writing, updating, and correcting technical documentation. In this article, you will learn how to automate your documentation workflow with Vale and GitHub Actions.
articles.title: How To Automate Documentation Workflow For Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Robin Marx)
articles.description: After almost five years in development, the new HTTP/3 protocol is nearing its final form. Letâ€™s take a close look at the performance improvements of HTTP/3, congestion control, head-of-line-blocking, and 0-RTT connection set-up.
articles.title: HTTP/3: Performance Improvements (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Mike Neumegen)
articles.description: The story of Jamstack CMSs goes all the way back to the 90s. In this article, we take a trip down memory lane to see how we got to the modern Jamstack CMSs we have today, and where theyâ€™re heading in the next decade.
articles.title: Jamstack CMS: The Past, The Present and The Future

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Devin Harold)
articles.description: Through a simple step-by-step approach, you can build an ethical practice within your organization that will ensure youâ€™re respecting the dignity and welfare of your research participants.
articles.title: How To Build An Ethical User Research Practice At Any Organization

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Anna Prenzel)
articles.description: In this article, we will code a Gantt chart as a reusable Web component. We will focus on the architecture of the component, rendering the calendar with CSS Grid and managing the state of the draggable tasks with JavaScript Proxy Objects.
articles.title: Creating An Interactive Gantt Chart Component With Vanilla JavaScript

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Your project is on a tight budget? Weâ€™ve collected some wonderful, free icons and goodies that weâ€™ve discovered lately and that are bound to give your design the finishing touch. Weâ€™ve also just recently covered [Figma plugins](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/08/figma-tools-plugins-resources/), [SVG generators](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/svg-generators/), [accessible front-end components](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/complete-guide-accessible-front-end-components/) and [front-end boilerplates](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/06/useful-frontend-boilerplates-starter-kits/) â€” you might find them useful, too.
articles.title: Free Open-Source Icons

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cache Merril)
articles.description: Software development without a roadmap is akin to driving off a cliff â€” an undertaking that seriously jeopardizes your productâ€™s life. Hereâ€™s how to develop a business technology roadmap that ensures your project safely reaches its final destination.
articles.title: How To Develop Your Businessâ€™ Technology Roadmap

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Janet John)
articles.description: Useful Figma plugins that will help you fix all the little slowdowns and boost your productivity. From color management and image assets to SVG shapes and animation. Thatâ€™s our new guide to Figma.
articles.title: Useful Figma Plugins And Tools

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Iris LjeÅ¡njanin)
articles.description: How do we build and establish a successful, bulletproof design system? Whatâ€™s the state of HTML Email? And what are new, smart interface design patterns we could use? Letâ€™s find out. With our [brand new online workshops](https://smashingconf.com/online-workshops/) on front-end & design â€” to help us all boost skills online.
articles.title: New Smashing Workshops on Front-End & Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Daniel Don)
articles.description: Often you need two different sets of navigation stacks for pre and post user authentication. Usually, to see more content, you have to be authenticated in some way. Letâ€™s look at how to mount and unmount navigation stack based on a met condition in React Native.
articles.title: Handling Mounting And Unmounting Of Navigation Routes In React Native

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Henrik Fricke)
articles.description: Embedding code examples with third-party scripts often leads to tracking or cookies. We always wanted to have a simple website with a good UX, so setting cookies for no reason wasnâ€™t an option for us. Now, with Indiepen, we are proud to introduce a privacy-friendly alternative.
articles.title: Cookieless Alternative To Embed HTML, CSS And JS Code Snippets

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, weâ€™re talking about designing for safety. What does it mean to consider vulnerable users in our designs? Drew McLellan talks to expert Eva PenzeyMoog to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 41 With Eva PenzeyMoog: Designing For Safety

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Robin Marx)
articles.description: What exactly is HTTP/3? Why was it needed so soon after HTTP/2 (which was only finalized in 2015)? How can or should you use it? And especially, how does this improve web performance? Letâ€™s find out.
articles.title: HTTP/3 From A To Z: Core Concepts (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Leonardo Losoviz)
articles.description: VS Code can be supercharged wuth hundreds of [VS Code extensions](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/05/useful-vs-code-extensions-web-developers/). In this article, Leonardo shares four useful extensions that help him in his daily work.
articles.title: Four Useful VSCode Extensions For Web Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: How can we make disabled buttons more inclusive? When do they work well, and when do they fail on us? And finally, when do we actually need them, and how can we avoid them? Letâ€™s find out.
articles.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Disabled Buttons

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Arihant Verma)
articles.description: In this article, weâ€™ll discuss and learn about the use case of iterating over React `children` and the ways to do it. In particular, we will deep dive into one of the utility methods, `React.Children.toArray`, that React gives us, which helps to iterate over the children in a way which ensures performance and determinism.
articles.title: React Children And Iteration Methods

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Callum Hart)
articles.description: Resilience is intrinsic to the web and therefore us, web developers. This article explores how graceful degradation, defensive coding, observability, and a healthy attitude towards failures better equips us before, during, and after an error occurs.
articles.title: How To Build Resilient JavaScript UIs

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: In this article, weâ€™ll take a deep dive into the refactoring process itself, and cover incremental refactoring strategy, visual regression testing, and maintaining the refactored codebase.
articles.title: Refactoring CSS: Strategy, Regression Testing And Maintenance (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: New month, new wallpapers! In this post, youâ€™ll find unique and inspiring wallpapers for August 2021. Created with love by the community for the community, they come in versions with and without a calendar for the month.
articles.title: Good Vibes In August (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: Having an e-commerce store is crucial for any store owner as more and more customers are turning to online shopping. In this tutorial, we shall go through how to create an e-commerce site with Angular 11. The site will use the Commerce Layer as a headless e-commerce API and use Paypal to process payments.
articles.title: How To Build An E-Commerce Site With Angular 11, Commerce Layer And Paypal

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Elad Shechter)
articles.description: What are absolute units? What are the differences between relative and absolute units, and how do we create accurate sizes on the web? In this article, Elad Shechter explains why CSS absolute units arenâ€™t so absolute.
articles.title: There Is No Such Thing As A CSS Absolute Unit

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kitty Giraudel)
articles.description: Dialogs are everywhere in modern interface design (for good or for bad), and yet many of them are not accessible to assistive technologies. In this article, we will dig into how to create a short script to create accessible dialogs.
articles.title: Creating An Accessible Dialog From Scratch

articles.description: In 2012, Harvard Business Review named data science the sexiest job of the 21st century. But if you want to get a job as a data scientist, you'll need to go through a tough interview process. During data science job interviews, the interviewer will likely ask questions from different data
articles.title: Data Science Interview Questions for Beginners

articles.description: JSON stands for JavaScript Object Notation. A JSON file has .json as its extension and the data inside are represented in a key:value pair, just like a traditional JavaScript object.  JSON and objects aren't exactly the same, though. The core difference is that the key in JSON must be
articles.title: What is a JSON File? Example JavaScript Code

articles.description: IntroductionAre you curious about the IoT (Internet of Things?) Have you always wanted to try to make your own robot, smart mirror, or bird feeder camera? What about building a computer for a fraction of the cost of a commercially available machine? If you said yes to any of these
articles.title: What is Raspberry Pi? Specs and Models (2021 Guide)

articles.description: JavaScript was created over 26 years ago and is currently one of the most popular programming languages. But what is JavaScript?  JavaScript is used with HTML and CSS to create dynamic and interactive web pages and mobile applications. We often call it one of the building blocks of web development.
articles.title: What is JavaScript? JavaScript Code Explained in Plain English

articles.description: Today we're gonna learn how to use the CSS units EM, REM, VW and VH by working through some practical examples. We'll also see how to make responsive websites with these units.  Let's start. ğŸ’– Table of ContentsWhy learn relative units?What are REM Units?How to make responsive websites with
articles.title: Learn CSS Units â€“ Em, Rem, VH, and VW with Code Examples âœ¨âœ¨

articles.description: Outliers are an important part of a dataset. They can hold useful information about your data.  Outliers can give helpful insights into the data you're studying, and they can have an effect on statistical results. This can potentially help you disover inconsistencies and detect any errors in your statistical processes.
articles.title: What is an Outlier? Definition and How to Find Outliers in Statistics

articles.description: You can use extensions in your browser to remove parts of a webpage you don't want to see. Removing annoyances, distractions, and irrelevant content is a great way to stay focused and remain efficient while you consume information on the internet. There are many extensions that add this functionality to
articles.title: How to Block Unwanted Content From Web Pages Using uBlock Origin

articles.description: What if you could monitor your Colab, Kaggle, or AzureML Machine Learning projects on your mobile phone? You'd be able to check in on your models on the fly â€“ even while taking a walkğŸš¶.  If you are an ML developer, you know how training models can easily take a long
articles.title: How to Monitor Machine Learning Projects on Your Mobile DeviceğŸ“±

articles.description: Python has a bunch of helpful built-in functions you can use to do all sorts of stuff. And each one performs a specific task.  But did you know that Python also allows you to define your own functions?  This article will show you how to create and call your own
articles.title: Python Function Examples â€“ How to Declare and Invoke with Parameters

articles.description: When you're working with an application, sometimes it no longer makes sense to try to continue and improve what already exists. Instead, you need to rethink, restructure, and rebuild.  Making the decision to give up all the work you and others have put into the existing system is a difficult
articles.title: Sacrificial Architecture â€“ How to Make Tough Decisions to Abandon and Rebuild Systems
